Hello,

      In experiments I've done with Half-field Offense, I alte=
red the way that the paths are representing by making the magnitude of the =
value 1.0 / (1.0 + distance), where distance is the distance between the en=
d points of the path.  In this way, the concept of distances gets somewhat =
injected into the domain.  Alternatively, if you want to more directly enco=
urage shorter distance plays, the magnitude of the teammate values could be=
 scaled with distance as well.

      I've never attempted to control attac=
kers without the ball, or defenders.  If they are all choosing the same act=
ion, it may be beneficial to more clearly distinguish states by either usin=
g path drawing again (to the player whose action is being chosen) or alteri=
ng their values, such that they are more dinstinct.  


     Alternatively,=
 the way actions are selected may need to be adjusted, by using some heuris=
tics to limit their choices.  For example, attackers without the ball could=
 be limited to selecting only nearby locations, or from some pre-determined=
 most open locations.  Defenders could be limited to marking the closest at=
tacker to them, or the choice to intercept the ball could be closed to them=
 unless they are one of the closest players to the ball.  Finally, selectio=
n of the highest value as the action may not be the best approach for parti=
cular actions.  For example, in selecting a position to move to, the value =
closest to zero may be best, since it conceptually could indicate a region =
that fewer players are exerting influence on.  

Regards,

Phillip

neat@yahoogroups.com, "yyyyaun" <yyyyaun@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I am tryi=
ng to use HyperNEAT for action selection in the half field offense task (Ro=
boCup soccer) for both the attacker and defender team and have some problem=
s regarding the state representation.
> 
> So far I have used the same stat=
e representation as in Stanley's and Verbancsics' paper "Evolving static re=
presentations for task transfer" (BEV).
> I have 3 different ANNs for actio=
n selection of the attacker with ball (dribble, pass, shoot), attacker with=
out ball (move to open position) and defender (mark player, intercept ball)=
.
> 
> Attacker with ball:
> The input layer is marked with the positions o=
f attacker with ball (+1), attackers without ball (+0.5), position of the g=
oal posts (+0.5), positions of defenders (-1), paths from attacker with bal=
l to its teammates (+0.3), to defenders (-0.3) and to the goal posts (+0.3)=
. The highest output value determines the action: dribble towards goal (at =
attacker with ball position), pass (at teammate position) or shoot (at goal=
 post position).
> The achieved performance is a little bit better than a s=
imple handcoded solution, but I wonder a few things:
> The solution is not =
really aware of the distances of the attacker with ball to its teammates an=
d to the goal, which results in attempted shots from the middle line and pa=
sses to teammates far away. I tried using path values corresponding to the =
distances and no paths at all, but the performance is similar. I also tried=
 to use a lengthCppn-input (as in the visual discrimination task), but that=
 does not show any performance gain.
> Is there a better way to represent t=
he state and shoot action?
> 
> 
> Attacker without ball:
> The input layer=
 is marked with the position of attacker with ball (+1), attackers without =
ball (+0.5) except the attacker requesting an action and defenders (-1). Th=
e highest output value determines the position to which the agent should mo=
ve.
> This does not work at all. All attackers tend to move to the same pos=
itions.
> 
> Defenders:
> The input layer is marked with the position of at=
tackers (-1), positions of teammates (+0.5) and the defender requesting an =
action (+1). The highest output value determines wether to intercept the ba=
ll (at attacker with ball position) or to mark an attacker (at attacker wit=
hout ball position).
> This representation suffers the same problem as atta=
ckers without ball: all defenders execute the same action (mark same player=
, intercept ball).
> 
> I probably miss something because this is my first =
experiment with HyperNEAT. I'd appreciate any tips for the representation o=
f the state in the input layer, especially for attackers without ball and d=
efenders.
> 
> Kind regards,
> Thomas
